samples.context: Microorganisms are classified into four major groups: bacteria, fungi, protozoa, and some algae. Some of the common microorganisms are shown in Figs. 2.1 - 2.4. Viruses are also microscopic but are different from other microorganisms.
samples.question: What are the four major groups of microorganisms?

samples.context: Common ailments like cold, influenza (flu), and most coughs are caused by viruses. Serious diseases like polio and chicken pox are also caused by viruses.
samples.question: Which diseases are caused by viruses?

samples.context: Microorganisms are so small in size that they cannot be seen with the unaided eye. Some of these, such as the fungus that grows on bread, can be seen with a magnifying glass.
samples.question: Why are microorganisms called microbes?

samples.context: Observe these patches through a magnifying glass. You will see tiny, black rounded structures. Do you know what these structures are and where do these come from?
samples.question: What can you observe on spoiled bread?

samples.context: Diseases like dysentery and malaria are caused by protozoa, whereas typhoid and tuberculosis (TB) are bacterial diseases. You have learned about some of these microorganisms in Classes VI and VII.
samples.question: What types of diseases are caused by bacteria?
